", "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 3, "parent_id": "b0d26615435bc62ab2978193daf09980", "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "Title", "element_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574", "text": "1. INTRODUCTION", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 4, "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "NarrativeText", "element_id": "5e05788935825b46f3841b8aac868360", "text": "Fishes have long been considered useful indicators of environmental and ecological integrity. As a result, they are increasingly being employed as physiological and biomedical models in life science research. Amongst the most aquatic species, Zebrafish are routinely being used as experimental models as environmental indicators and as substitutes for higher sentient laboratory animals for use in pharmacological, toxicological, genetic, and biomedical research and testing. It is known that fish can also perceive stimuli that are damaging or potentially damaging to normal tissue (noxious stimuli) like mechanical pressure, extremes of temperature, and corrosive chemicals. However, their capacity to experience adverse conditions associated with pain as in mammals has been debated. The use of fish as a replacement for mammals as experimental subjects has been enhanced over the years. Different fisheries, institutes and universities use various inland and marine fish, including Cyprinids like the Indian major carps (IMC), Salmonids like Rainbow and Brown trout for both aquaculture and experimental purposes besides Zebrafish.", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 4, "parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574", "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "NarrativeText", "element_id": "27329efe95009a40513800e047a40f1d", "text": "Humane procedures involving holding, handling, and sampling fish are quite essential to reduce pain or discomfort experienced by experimental subjects. The investigators, animal ethics committees, facility managers, and animal care staff need to be well informed about the care and use of fish for experimental, research, or teaching purposes. These guidelines would enable them to assist in providing proper care and humane use of fish in experimental procedures and to avoid unnecessary infliction of pain or suffering on these creatures.

",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 4,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "27329efe95009a40513800e047a40f1d",
"text": "Humane procedures involving holding, handling, and sampling fish are quite essential to reduce pain or discomfort experienced by experimental subjects. The investigators, animal ethics committees, facility managers, and animal care staff need to be well informed about the care and use of fish for experimental, research, or teaching purposes. These guidelines would enable them to assist in providing proper care and humane use of fish in experimental procedures and to avoid unnecessary infliction of pain or suffering on these creatures.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 4,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d9afb1607cd3908961667e7ba4876e30",
"text": "The use of fish in research, teaching, and testing requires specific ethical considerations that need to be followed. Fish should be treated with respect equal to the other vertebrate species and must be used only if the non-animal models have failed, not available, or not possible. The least likely numbers of fish should be used in such a way that the quality of the experiment is not compromised, whether it is for a laboratory or a field trial. Pilot studies should be preferred for conducting an investigation in vitro than in vivo if any. Fish should be maintained in an environment that will match to their natural habitat to keep them in optimal health and wellbeing conditions, besides maintaining consistency with the demands of the experimental protocol. Fishes should not be subjected to any kind of noxious stimulus (pain or distress unless required by the experimental procedure). Further following points should be followed while conducting experiments on fishes:",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 4,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b2ca5820c35854488a355a679c330e0e",
"text": "1. Experimental protocols should be framed for the use of fish in research, teaching, or testing, and prior approval of IAEC must be obtained before the commencement of experimentation on fish.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 4,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b171b231b30a2035765ea7445e8d6ee3",
"text": "2. Training should be provided to all the personnel (investigators, technical staff, and students) involved in experimentation with fish. The outcome of the training must be evaluated for competence.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 4,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "ff34af7274b811c8985f758478d3bc0d",
"text": "1",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 4,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "5218deca94413a91a8c5a1e6f2572f53",
"text": "3.

It is the responsibility of the investigators to comply with occupational health and safety regulations for the protection of personnel from known or suspected physical and biological hazards as the case may be. While conducting experiments involving fish pathogens, biosafety guidelines should also be kept in mind.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "52b6182a9c62599d60c76ac40de2d021",
"text": "4. Due care must be taken while working with zoonotic pathogens from fish.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "a645b7651ecdf8720ff0c6ed40b4d574",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "767d44cb4459be38b7a60d817dc6864f",
"text": "2. GOAL",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d07624e970f3fe0a1f3d3892acd9a791",
"text": "The goal of these Guidelines is to promote the humane care and use of fish in research, testing, and training with the primary objective of providing specifications that will enhance quality in the pursuit of the advancement of biological knowledge relevant to humans, animals, and fish. Good Laboratory Practices (GLP) are intended to assure quality maintenance and welfare of fish used in laboratory studies while conducting biomedical research and product testing.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "767d44cb4459be38b7a60d817dc6864f",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "9624192d78f372e63e0d6260f958dbfc",
"text": "3. FISH PROCUREMENT",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "a8b43c09407714297784f45c3e375012",
"text": "Acquisition, exchange, transport of, or research on fish must be carried out strictly as per the guidelines, and the personnel must be familiar with relevant legislation. Compliance with the policies governing the capture of fishes and their transfer from one water body or jurisdiction to another should be adhered to as it may lead to introduction of new pathogens.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "9624192d78f372e63e0d6260f958dbfc",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "453b89095138471863edd1883a8d67e9",
"text": "Investigators must acquire fish as per the CPCSEA guidelines from wild habitat, commercial hatcheries, breeding farms, establishments registered with CPCSEA. Various species of fish listed in Annexure 1.

Compliance with the policies governing the capture of fishes and their transfer from one water body or jurisdiction to another should be adhered to as it may lead to introduction of new pathogens.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "9624192d78f372e63e0d6260f958dbfc",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "453b89095138471863edd1883a8d67e9",
"text": "Investigators must acquire fish as per the CPCSEA guidelines from wild habitat, commercial hatcheries, breeding farms, establishments registered with CPCSEA. Various species of fish listed in Annexure 1.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "9624192d78f372e63e0d6260f958dbfc",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"text": "Conditions for Procurement:",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "5cad783aa8efc9c519c6ce8ace6f166b",
"text": "1. The use of any kind of piscicidal compounds should be discouraged for fish acquisition from natural bodies. Instead, anesthetic agents with minimal impact on the environment and non-target species should be considered.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "2dbf1e27c4cc05d37191c07c866c973d",
"text": "2. Methods like electro fishing and netting should be carried out, ensuring with minimum impact on fish being caught.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c10a0a446678d95968d268cad5e10b99",
"text": "3. Minimal morbidity and mortality must be ensured while capturing, transportion, and handling of wild fishes.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "ListItem",
"element_id": "fffb40f1b0ec626218cba084c2ac3b28",
"text": "4. The risk of escape and the accidental introduction of exotic/infectious diseases and other detrimental outcomes resulting from the introduction of unknown or non-native species must be taken into account. 5.

Minimal morbidity and mortality must be ensured while capturing, transportion, and handling of wild fishes.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "ListItem",
"element_id": "fffb40f1b0ec626218cba084c2ac3b28",
"text": "4. The risk of escape and the accidental introduction of exotic/infectious diseases and other detrimental outcomes resulting from the introduction of unknown or non-native species must be taken into account. 5. If fish are procured from registered vendors, research organizations, national or international repositories, their health status, and preferably known genetic",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "528ef2bc0b260176f065ea4cf7fc0b41",
"text": "2",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 5,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "806a42806a11818800549d3790fd5fd8",
"text": "history should also be obtained.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "10a3438a6077d733b1b2cf9a466ad1ba",
"text": "6. Consistent husbandry and management practices should be adopted with developed SOPs in the fish facilities like in any other laboratory animal production facilities.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "3e127859e06e3cedda064c6c893c3fd3",
"text": "7. inspected for compliance with procurement specifications, and the fish should be quarantined and stabilized according to procedures appropriate for the species and circumstances.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "4da688fdcedd06d8476ad75c2ff864f5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"text": "4. QUARANTINE AND ACCLIMATION",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c3eb6118176d2251f817274dc5556f5f",
"text": "1. Quarantine is the separation of newly received fish from those already in the facility until the health and possibly the microbial status of the newly acquired fish have been determined. Effective quarantine minimizes the chance of introduction of pathogens into the established stock.

QUARANTINE AND ACCLIMATION",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c3eb6118176d2251f817274dc5556f5f",
"text": "1. Quarantine is the separation of newly received fish from those already in the facility until the health and possibly the microbial status of the newly acquired fish have been determined. Effective quarantine minimizes the chance of introduction of pathogens into the established stock.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "24d45aa97ae10f3986ee9f8c93c0a759",
"text": "2. For maintenance and housing of different fish species, separate rooms and separate attendants are required. Sick fish must be isolated and kept separately, and a separate set of personnel should be identified for taking care of these sick fish, and other workers should be restricted from entering into the facilities unless otherwise required. After handling these fish, they should not be handling any other fish in the facilities.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "541356bf5fcc6f6a6e03c8204a4858b9",
"text": "3. Once the caught or acquired fish reaches its destination lab or field, they must be kept under quarantine for two weeks period and allowed to acclimatize to the new conditions.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d7a10632342e2a60ec90e251c1c5476c",
"text": "4. Under no circumstances fish from two or more different sources should be mixed. All acquired fish should be quarantined separately, and the quarantine areas should be under constant vigilance. All morbidities and mortalities must be recorded and good record-keeping must be practiced to detect and respond to any health problems of fish during quarantine period.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "fd28f1f1f16191e3115b50aa72fa23f5",
"text": "5. The quarantine duration should be appropriate to assure the health of the fishes (usually 14 days). However, the period of quarantine may be extended if fish are suspected of any infection for further tests. On confirmation of any infectious disease, they should not be allowed to continue in the facility either for experiments or for breeding purposes.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"text": "5.

The quarantine duration should be appropriate to assure the health of the fishes (usually 14 days). However, the period of quarantine may be extended if fish are suspected of any infection for further tests. On confirmation of any infectious disease, they should not be allowed to continue in the facility either for experiments or for breeding purposes.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "b7c57df659f7a5bd64fbd8e8860f7b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"text": "5. AQUATIC FACILITIES",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "8ce748b750a74531556265a89b77d1ec",
"text": "a. Facilities for aquatic species must be designed in such a way to minimize stress to the fish being reared for experimental or breeding purposes. Quality water appropriate to species (brackish, sea, or freshwater) should be chosen to enable",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "0a4c362e47a40440a1a92d7cc92e82d4",
"text": "3",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 6,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "1645d3a44c74fa4805413426c9c7e133",
"text": "efficient operation of the facility and ensure a safe working environment for personnel.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "101ff49036476a68fffa7c280f812bf6",
"text": "b. Water Quality Water used for fish culture should be clean and available in abundance. It should be regularly tested and adequately treated to remove contaminants and pathogens. Adequate water supply of suitable quality should be provided for the fish at all times.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b716656f183c6c5d18845a9ffe46a247",
"text": "Engineering and design c. 1. The assistance of the experienced civil engineers and subject experts should be involved in designing and construction of aquatic facilities. Corrosion-free and water-resistant construction materials should be used for the construction of fish housing facilities. The use of toxic materials in aquatic facilities should be strictly avoided. However, if they require to be used as part of experimentation and testing, they should be permitted to use in minimum quantities judiciously with proper justification and permissions and, the list of those toxic material should be readily available to the staff to rule out the intolerable effects.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c8df6dc5671bf617bd20d3ebd17bc885",
"text": "2.

Corrosion-free and water-resistant construction materials should be used for the construction of fish housing facilities. The use of toxic materials in aquatic facilities should be strictly avoided. However, if they require to be used as part of experimentation and testing, they should be permitted to use in minimum quantities judiciously with proper justification and permissions and, the list of those toxic material should be readily available to the staff to rule out the intolerable effects.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c8df6dc5671bf617bd20d3ebd17bc885",
"text": "2. To ensure the adequate ventilation of aquatic areas, air handling systems must be in place with humidity controllers and to guarantee minimum transfer of aerosol between tanks. Vibration and noise producing machinery should preferably be isolated from fish housing areas.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d38d442a1209b43ceaa295c0da0a3d67",
"text": "3. Ensure installation of quality electrical systems suitable for operation in moist environments. The electricals must include proper grounding and ground fault interrupters on all circuits. All electrical wires conduits should be fixed safely away from water pipelines, and from water circulation areas. The use of extension cords should strictly be avoided to prevent accidents.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b276d659582c50c25634d131cbf8e778",
"text": "4. Electrical components and equipment should be located outside splash zones and housed in moisture-proof enclosures. Electrical fixtures should be secured well with gaskets to prevent the incursion of water and should be located away from pipe runs. Alternate systems, including pumps, motors and critical aeration programming systems should be duplicated to ensure 100 percent back up and to overcome failures and service interruptions.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "7898ff7edf31f8035b7de3192db7fbab",
"text": "5. Light and dark cycles should be maintained within the facility to adjust light wavelengths and intensities appropriate for the species where it is known. Where lighting is needed for people to work in the room, it should be restricted in its dispersion and be placed at a lower level than the tank surface.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "aebce82372e4e42ce3bb8573aaf3a9cb",
"text": "6. All aquatic facilities should have an emergency contingency plan for maintaining aerated and filtered water and assuring the continuation of life support in case of any kind of water crisis.

Light and dark cycles should be maintained within the facility to adjust light wavelengths and intensities appropriate for the species where it is known. Where lighting is needed for people to work in the room, it should be restricted in its dispersion and be placed at a lower level than the tank surface.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "aebce82372e4e42ce3bb8573aaf3a9cb",
"text": "6. All aquatic facilities should have an emergency contingency plan for maintaining aerated and filtered water and assuring the continuation of life support in case of any kind of water crisis.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "d88a9ab202fe000611c41905a4366e8c",
"text": "4",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 7,
"parent_id": "319f162ff052ad2aaa79350749079bc5",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"text": "d. Housing",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "3391a679de61da98837b91c3ba03ae97",
"text": "1. Aquatic housing environments should be designed to meet the established physical and behavioural requirements for fish wellbeing like shelter, social grouping, overhead cover, and lighting.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "ceb8d6d316681767fe878de269327048",
"text": "2. species and life stage being held. The shape, colour, depth, and volume of tanks should be appropriate for the",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "0b4b0a30d154fe347efefb03008fa01d",
"text": "3. facility of self-cleaning and regular cleaning. The tanks used should have smooth, inert, sealed interior surfaces with a",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "364c0e943df903a6bde2f1e7ed051f41",
"text": "4. adequately covered with suitable nets.

The tanks used should have smooth, inert, sealed interior surfaces with a",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "364c0e943df903a6bde2f1e7ed051f41",
"text": "4. adequately covered with suitable nets. To prevent the fish from jumping out of the tanks, the tanks need to be",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "853f9355a2242fd97c9d1ed75d3911b6",
"text": "5. well-placed electricals for connecting aerators and water heaters. The wet lab should have a constant supply of clean water, adequate light and",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "aeb72472e80bc9db64cb312448b0c49f",
"text": "6. Use of extension boards should be avoided.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "cb63937f98a78f0f3f6b9b5fd765fbf3",
"text": "7. Controlled feeding should be practiced to prevent wastage of feed that may invite fish diseases. Likewise, re-circulatory systems must meet the basic requirements along with constant power supply to prevent fish loss. Besides, the basic infrastructure and clean water, re-circulatory systems and raceways should have restricted entry.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "c10d919fda0f88377be1aebfc3f19b05",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "2df6557a80b93a9d44e6135352293919",
"text": "6. FACILITY MANAGEMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "25f77c01fd2b33fb4a2b05b096f41da4",
"text": "a. Access to fish facilities should be designed to minimize traffic through the area. Access should be restricted to delineate personnel involved in the maintenance of the facility, caring for the fish, and those using the facilities for experiments or teaching.

FACILITY MANAGEMENT, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "25f77c01fd2b33fb4a2b05b096f41da4",
"text": "a. Access to fish facilities should be designed to minimize traffic through the area. Access should be restricted to delineate personnel involved in the maintenance of the facility, caring for the fish, and those using the facilities for experiments or teaching.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "2df6557a80b93a9d44e6135352293919",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"text": "b. General Maintenance of the Facility",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c62c56f06928b08aeea99dc4e98659f6",
"text": "1. round the year for both routine and emergency needs. Sufficient staff must be available for care and management of fish facility",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "10c5f39ba5cf3d46d44c6e5510429b3d",
"text": "2. All architectural and engineering specifications and drawings of the facility should be available to those in charge of running the facility, as well as all operating manuals of special equipment such as pumps, chillers, and computer control systems.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "95bfce1702ca936f4c68e043c08a0964",
"text": "3. Aquatic facilities must have written maintenance schedules explicitly developed for the facility.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "7291a5705db7ff280ad22d00c49aff90",
"text": "5",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 8,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "195764c37e713127c18ae28c1d7cee54",
"text": "4. Facilities should be kept in a clean and orderly manner. Tanks/tubs/boxes, lids, baffles, water sumps and plumbing should be disinfected with tested disinfectants before and after every experiment, ensure no residual contents of disinfectants after cleaning.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "487d5ca01bf339adb9d7052d5df64b7c",
"text": "5.

Facilities should be kept in a clean and orderly manner. Tanks/tubs/boxes, lids, baffles, water sumps and plumbing should be disinfected with tested disinfectants before and after every experiment, ensure no residual contents of disinfectants after cleaning.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "487d5ca01bf339adb9d7052d5df64b7c",
"text": "5. The staff responsible for operating an aquatic facility should have the specialized knowledge, experience, and training for proper functional, operational, and maintenance of the water systems.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "dac6c264c633fcbc23ea52b4de16c7d2",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"text": "c. Environmental Monitoring and Control",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "9b7459faaf94369f1e1f28eb5ffe4b61",
"text": "1. be designed to suit the water management system. Environmental monitoring system is essential for aquatic facilities and should",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "4ec21b620cc8fde7123851220226f975",
"text": "2. Water quality must be monitored and maintained within acceptable parameters for the species being held (Annexure 2).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "570b0f9f4ba849ed205a1945c39063c8",
"text": "3. rapid increases in temperature. Fishes should not be subjected to rapid changes in temperature, particularly to",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "433ab724a0f92c5aef7a6fdd8564b310",
"text": "4. Water quality monitoring systems should be able to detect and react to changes in water quality and give alarm before they become life-threatening to fish housed in the system.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b971197fce6700725b03409c8385c492",
"text": "5. Water quality parameters should be regularly monitored at an appropriate frequency in the facility to permit predictive rather than reactive management of crises (Annexure 3).

Water quality monitoring systems should be able to detect and react to changes in water quality and give alarm before they become life-threatening to fish housed in the system.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b971197fce6700725b03409c8385c492",
"text": "5. Water quality parameters should be regularly monitored at an appropriate frequency in the facility to permit predictive rather than reactive management of crises (Annexure 3).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "4a2e1c3fc69bd293eaeb0b2b03f26a75",
"text": "6. Good water quality measuring equipment should be available in adequate numbers within the facility and they should be regularly calibrated and well maintained.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "1c1149cda2b8d6dfcd84ab3a7062c1ea",
"text": "7. retrospective analysis if any problem is encountered. Records of water quality, testing should be maintained and retrievable for",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "be1eb8cebfa931240280c8f2addb05dc",
"text": "Fishes should be kept in water with an adequate concentration of oxygen.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "93c64e30eff4a0956b5f75600fd8d76f",
"text": "8.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d4f19d6518107f37647ba27a4298a35a",
"text": "9. Aquatic systems are susceptible to acute or chronic super saturation. This may lead to gas super saturation resulting in serious problems. Individuals responsible for operating aquatic systems should be made aware of its consequences to mitigate such issues.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "28d1fe1c977aaad9949bb21b596a841d",
"text": "10. Changes in pH may influence other water quality parameters; therefore, pH of the water being used in the facility should be properly maintained all times at a stable and optimal level.

Aquatic systems are susceptible to acute or chronic super saturation. This may lead to gas super saturation resulting in serious problems. Individuals responsible for operating aquatic systems should be made aware of its consequences to mitigate such issues.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "28d1fe1c977aaad9949bb21b596a841d",
"text": "10. Changes in pH may influence other water quality parameters; therefore, pH of the water being used in the facility should be properly maintained all times at a stable and optimal level.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d79a63013d1855458a4b72599375cfd6",
"text": "11. Measures should be in place to prevent the accumulation of free Ammonia",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "7475cb61fa496918175c3a12567c523b",
"text": "6",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 9,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "978954b3b7c28371c453076c12b6ab66",
"text": "and nitrites as they are toxic to fishes.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d78b4837928e12f785623c86144f18bf",
"text": "12. Changes in salinity should be made slowly and with attention to the physical status of the fishes. This procedure is known to be stressful for fishes.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "786dfd43648e01d13fc0fbb5e55491a6",
"text": "13. accidentally entered the water system, it should be isolated and tested.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "613d684d6a5ecc90503c60fe26246627",
"text": "14. Chemicals used in the facility should be safely stored away from the aquatic housing area and the water supply.

", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 10, "parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b", "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "NarrativeText", "element_id": "613d684d6a5ecc90503c60fe26246627", "text": "14. Chemicals used in the facility should be safely stored away from the aquatic housing area and the water supply.", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 10, "parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b", "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "NarrativeText", "element_id": "22612d38c728e94fbde359de744ad21b", "text": "15. Following are the Physical parameters and normal values for laboratory Zebra fish (Source: Zebra fish in Biomedical Research; Biology, Husbandry, Diseases and Research Applications. American College of Laboratory Animal Medicine series, 2020).", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 10, "parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b", "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "Table", "element_id": "347ed2a2a168176f541805414943e493", "text": "Sr. No. Parameters Normal Values 1 Room temperature (oC) 28-29 2 Relative humidity (%) 70 3 Light intensity (Lux) 300 4 Photoperiod (Light : Dark) 14:10 5 Noise/vibration Free (if possible)", "metadata": { "text_as_html": "
Sr. No.ParametersNormal Values
1Room temperature (©C)28-29
2Relative humidity (%)70
3Light intensity (Lux)300
4Photoperiod (Light : Dark)14:10
5Noise/vibrationFree (if possible)
", "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 10, "parent_id": "75bf1f9ad5ec4d23d5e195a932dce58b", "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "Title", "element_id": "438d0fc23a8510092d5e981f4bb6d2cd", "text": "7. HUSBANDRY", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 10, "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "Title", "element_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1", "text": "a. Density and carrying capacity", "metadata": { "filetype": "application/pdf", "languages": [ "eng" "page_number": 10, "filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf" "type": "NarrativeText", "element_id": "18aef1cc02dfa607875db33f81e18fb9", "text": "Fish species should be housed in clean experimental tanks at an optimum density to ensure the maintenance of a particular species, an ideal environment must be developed using performance-based criteria. Such environmental conditions should be followed for the said fish in the future. Moreover, under no circumstances, established maximum densities should not be exceeded (Annexure-4).

Such environmental conditions should be followed for the said fish in the future. Moreover, under no circumstances, established maximum densities should not be exceeded (Annexure-4).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "f45ddcc81c51db0ba5b7976a12269251",
"text": "b. Record-keeping and Documentation 1. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) should be developed",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "2f709a2cf065d66dafaf9ff95efb83c6",
"text": "fish disinfection/bleaching, procurement, larviculture, feeding, live feed preparation, water parameter monitoring, sanitation of tanks, rooms and equipment.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c172c23118a90e8601f19cf3de4476da",
"text": "2. Records of every cleaning, maintenance and experimental procedure must be",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "ea992c9c2a327f03a974c82f9da681e7",
"text": "7",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 10,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "4b9e26128b284063c42761fdd01bd7e1",
"text": "maintained and a checklist should be used for each group of fish.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "0abbb6550d76613d20b7324ecfeee185",
"text": "Wellbeing in fishes should be monitored daily and written records should be maintained along with basic physical and behavioral parameters. Any observational changes should be recorded and investigated to identify the cause and for corrections.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "4eb806465259d5ce899e63c282040c77",
"text": "3.

Any observational changes should be recorded and investigated to identify the cause and for corrections.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "4eb806465259d5ce899e63c282040c77",
"text": "3.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "e7b1058fc88fe70cb642d561bdc129f2",
"text": "c. Food, feeding and nutrition 1. Fish feed should be purchased from reliable sources that manufacture as per the standards formulation. However, if the feed produced in house, it should be in accordance with the published nutrient requirements for the species.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "c3b7c675ffb9e5233dcec2c41f99883a",
"text": "2. Purchased feed must be in sealed bags, that has proper label with date of manufacture, expiry and information of its contents, analysis / guarantee details etc. In case of procured feed, small aliquots should be retained for independent testing if required.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d46c46ac0ef826f11eb6bc217b4a3332",
"text": "3. Feed must be stored in dedicated storage areas and ensure the storehouse is pest- free and dark. The temperature and humidity of feed storage room must be controlled to ensure the feed's nutritional quality and prevent fungal growth and spoilage. Feed for daily consumption should be kept in sealed-top containers to protect it from humidity and light and frequently replaced with fresh feed from storage.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "3c781570e29bd5fa761bcefcc05166dd",
"text": "4. Feed must be provided adequately suitable to the life stage of fish at appropriate time points for proper growth, development, reproduction and good health leaving minimum scope for leftover uneaten feed as that would result in fouling (Annexure 5). However, uneaten feed should be siphoned off to prevent spoilage of water quality. Fish should be closely observed to determine their response to feed and signs of either over or underfeeding must be recorded.",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 11,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "d70619bf49817419865fbd5792be2e52",
"text": "5. Medicated feeds must only be used in exceptional conditions under the supervision of a fisheries/aquaculture expert.

However, uneaten feed should be siphoned off to prevent spoilage of water quality. Fish should be closely observed to determine their response to feed and signs of either over or underfeeding must be recorded.",

"text": "5. Medicated feeds must only be used in exceptional conditions under the supervision of a fisheries/aquaculture expert.",

"element_id": "ec96bc3f3ec77645afabd4402d0add73",
"text": "d. Broodstock and Breeding There should be appropriate holding systems and environmental conditions for the species being maintained. The importance of environmental cues for the maintenance or manipulation of endogenous reproductive rhythms should be in place for effective breeding. If possible, rational genetic management of broodstock should be employed. A strict disease and health control program should be implemented to ensure the production of healthy progeny and prevention of disease transmission through water sources, fish, or eggs.",
"metadata": {

"text": "8",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",

"eng"

"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "55624c0be019f7e999c0cc49573e6f91",
"text": "1. Breeding Zebrafish are generally kept under laboratory conditions designed to replicate perpetual summer. In wild habitat, depending upon food availability and temperature, they can breed all year round (Spence et al., 2006), with females generally producing eggs once every one to three days. Darkness allows the Zebrafish to rest and the return of light will trigger fish to breed (Vargesson, 2007). A layer of marbles, closely spaced rods, or mesh can be used to cover part or the whole of the bottom of the tank to prevent the fish from eating their eggs once laid (Matthews et al 2002). Females consistently spawn more frequently and produce larger clutches of eggs with some males than others. A good clutch consists of between 70 and 300 eggs, of which at least 80% are fertilized (Brand et al., 2002).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "cb5e37eefd244e6948e65e87cc466406",
"text": "A generalized description of the techniques and some of the equipment used in relation to the spawning process can be found in Lawrence (2007).

Females consistently spawn more frequently and produce larger clutches of eggs with some males than others. A good clutch consists of between 70 and 300 eggs, of which at least 80% are fertilized (Brand et al., 2002).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "cb5e37eefd244e6948e65e87cc466406",
"text": "A generalized description of the techniques and some of the equipment used in relation to the spawning process can be found in Lawrence (2007).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "db7f53b617e2038e91eb9ad781d6415f",
"text": "Typically: A small (typically <1L) plastic mating cage or box with a mesh or grill bottom is placed inside a slightly larger container that is filled with water; breeding pairs or small groups of fish are added to the box in the evening; when the fish spawn (usually the following morning), the fertilized eggs fall through the ‘floor’ of the inner box (which means the fish are prevented from eating them). It is possible for both males and females to reach sexual maturity within three months of hatching. Although establishments may begin using fish for breeding from this age (Kurtzman, 2010), initial batches of eggs from such young females may not be of optimal quality. The highest number of embryos is reported to be obtained from fish between 6 and 18 months of age (Vargesson, 2007). The mating behaviour of Zebrafish seems to be influenced by the exposure of mating partners to one another during the 24 hours before spawning begins (at sunrise), with males stimulated to perform courtship behaviour by the detection of female gonadal hormones in the water (Delaney et al., 2002). Source: Reed and Jennings, 2010",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "974791c3caa5d3abd125ac0cf8ce6ab0",
"text": "2. Raising of larvae Fertilized eggs are kept in an incubator (~28.5 °C) for 72 hr until the larvae are hatched. The embryos are reared in embryo medium; a.k.a. EM3 (NaCl, 13.7 mM; KCl, 0.54 mM; MgSO4, 1.0 mM; CaCl2, 1.3 mM; Na2HPO4, 0.025 mM; KH2PO4, 0.044 mM; NaHCO3, 4.2 mM) (Avdesh et al., 2012).

Raising of larvae Fertilized eggs are kept in an incubator (~28.5 °C) for 72 hr until the larvae are hatched. The embryos are reared in embryo medium; a.k.a. EM3 (NaCl, 13.7 mM; KCl, 0.54 mM; MgSO4, 1.0 mM; CaCl2, 1.3 mM; Na2HPO4, 0.025 mM; KH2PO4, 0.044 mM; NaHCO3, 4.2 mM) (Avdesh et al., 2012).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "99a38cb42142667b72e30012af918f19",
"text": "The different stages of the Zebrafish life cycle (Reed and Jennings, 2010) have been broadly established as follows (Fleming, 2007):",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "e8a92734649626bb5d30372d5c3681dd",
"text": "i. 0-72 hours post-fertilization - Embryos ii. 72 hours to 13 days post-fertilization - Early larvae iii. 14 days to 29 days post-fertilization - Mid larvae iv. 30 days to 3 or 4 months – Juveniles v. When sexually mature – Adults",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "69e7d6ac56a4df2d17a3a0b016f16eae",
"text": "Feeding of larvae should commence from 5 dpf (days post hatching). Young larvae can be fed with dry food of ~100 microns in size (e.g., ZM100) or live food such as",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "UncategorizedText",
"element_id": "d53223b576bee5f713d95f2ff19681dd",
"text": "9",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 12,
"parent_id": "3e72f2b6e75ad671c50715f790ce95a1",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "20afacf943081c276b8ae0be15b8f6a4",
"text": "paramecium and rotifers (which stimulates growth). The food size can slowly be increased to 200 microns (e.g. ZM200) or 300/400 microns (e.g. ZM300). A population of adult fish should be around 6-7 fish per liter of water. This practice is recommended to better maintain BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand) to the tanks (Avdesh et al., 2012).

The food size can slowly be increased to 200 microns (e.g. ZM200) or 300/400 microns (e.g. ZM300). A population of adult fish should be around 6-7 fish per liter of water. This practice is recommended to better maintain BOD (Biological Oxygen Demand) to the tanks (Avdesh et al., 2012). The relationship between feeding frequencies and development in Zebrafish is given below (Source: Lawerence, 2011):",

"element_id": "17c6f084b08622a4b6d879c18da7d171",
"text": "3. System Maintenance",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 13,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Title",
"element_id": "b4b1779763fa649a8e2d7b9167e52c69",
"text": "Re-circulatory system:",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 13,
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "8bd1ec3a6daff6c85d2979271a158b92",
"text": "Zebrafish are kept in a re-circulating water system that continuously treat and sterilizes the system water (effluent) before it re-enters into the aquaria to maintain the water quality required for a healthy aquatic environment. The re-circulating system also helps to filter excess food and fish excreta. Different companies provide circulating Zebrafish systems. A set of different kinds of filters are used in the system 120-micron filter pad, 50- micron canister filter, biological filter, activated carbon absorption filter and UV disinfection. The filters need to be changed regularly (Avdesh et al., 2012).",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 13,
"parent_id": "b4b1779763fa649a8e2d7b9167e52c69",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "NarrativeText",
"element_id": "b524f4816fbf6751e74ae3a30eb76b78",
"text": "The other important features of Zebrafish rearing system that needs due care for wellbeing of Zebrafish are provided below:",
"metadata": {
"filetype": "application/pdf",
"languages": [
"eng"
"page_number": 13,
"parent_id": "b4b1779763fa649a8e2d7b9167e52c69",
"filename": "Guidelines of CPCSEA for Experimentation on Fishes-2021.pdf"
"type": "Table",
"element_id": "35baf83789694d0f09e832ad0cb1c097",
"text": "Sl. No. 1 Features Lighting Details A cycle of 14 hours light, and 10 hours dark has been advised and would appear to be common practice (Matthews et al., 2002; Brand et al., 2002).

No. 1 Features Lighting Details A cycle of 14 hours light, and 10 hours dark has been advised and would appear to be common practice (Matthews et al., 2002; Brand et al., 2002). Ideally, wherever artificial lighting is used, a gradual brightening/dimming period of around 20-30 minutes in the morning and evening can be incorporated. Light triggers Zebrafish to breed, so periods of darkness are important for allowing fish to rest (Vargesson, 2007; Brand et al., 2002). Francis (2008) states that, one of the fastest ways to ensure fish prevent laying eggs, is to leave the lights on all the time.", "metadata": { "text_as_html": "

Ideally, wherever artificial lighting is used, a gradual brightening/dimming period of around 20-30 minutes in the morning and evening can be incorporated. Light triggers Zebrafish to breed, so periods of darkness are important for allowing fish to rest (Vargesson, 2007; Brand et al., 2002). Francis (2008) states that, one of the fastest ways to ensure fish prevent laying eggs, is to leave the lights on all the time.

Zebrafish are often described as surface-living fish, yet field studies show that they occupy the whole of the water column, with no significant difference in their distribution according to depth (Spence et al., 2006). It has been recommended that as long as tanks have a ‘relatively large surface area,’ water depth does not have to exceed 25cm (Brand et al., 2002). Elsewhere it has been suggested that for spawning, just 10cm water depth in a 50-litre tank should be provided for three adult males and two females (Andrews, 1999). 20 eggs/embryos per 100ml water. 20 young larvae per 400ml up to juvenile stage. Growing juvenile fish and holding adults - 5 fish per litre. For breeding, a pair can be kept overnight in 1.5 litres, or 6 fish in 2 to 3 litres of water (Matthews et al., 2002) 5 fish per litre in systems possessing filters and a biofilter, as long as there is good water exchange, good feeding regime and good water quality. For breeding purposes it is best to have less fish per tank (2-3 fish per litre). In a tank that does not have filters or a biofilter, the maximum number should be 1 or 2 fish per litre (Vargesson, 2007). In large-scale re-circulating systems, families of sibling adult fish are kept in serial tanks at densities of 5 adult fish per litre (60 fish/12 litres) (Brand et al.,2002).

(e.g. Zebrafish to be Paramecium) predominantly visually guided (McElligott & O'Malley, 2005). Dry food alone is not sufficient to keep fish in good to breeding conditions. Therefore supplement it with live or frozen food. The most commonly used additional live food is Artemia nauplii, Rotifers, paramecium. Alternatively, or in addition to Artemia, Drosophila larvae or different types of frozen food that are available from aquaculture supply stores can be used. Live or frozen food (e.g. tubifex, Daphnia and Chironomus larvae) that has been harvested from freshwater systems that also harbour fish, should be avoided, as it may be a source of pathogens. On the other hand, salt-water-dwelling articulates are safe (e.g. frozen adult Artemia and krill). A typical feeding regimen is to feed adult fish tanks twice a day (once at weekends). Adult fish that have to be kept for longer periods of time without breeding require very little feeding (e.g. twice a week, preferably with live food). Two weeks of rich feeding will bring them back into breeding condition again (Brand et al., 2002). Newly hatched Zebrafish can eat Paramecium (800μm x 80μm), as well as a variety of prepared foods, infusoria and rotifers (Matthews et al., 2002).
